title: What will be the end-of-day spot price of an ounce of gold on 29 September 2017?
preds: Supply continues to pour in, technical pivot/resistance now ~$1290. Lots more work to reclaim $1300, probably months away.
this one's so tricky but it just needs one more inflammatory presidential tweet to hit my bucket.
4 days left, trend is down, no reason to adjust from the trend. Stable economic numbers. Not clear how bitcoin would affect gold, but something to look for
Price action around key $1300 pivot very weak. Recent GDX and GDXJ outflows show more precious metals selling pressure (lower prices) into October.

10 days to go. Hovering around 1300. I guess it will go lower as US rates were not increased in September which favours QE in December more than rate increase. Which means less likelihood of further tightening and more legs in asset bubbles.

The Dollar is stabilizing at the moment and will stay between 1.18 and 1.25 for the next few weeks. The crisis are calming, the world get used to USA/North Korea conflict and the natural disasters prevent Donald Trump to make another rush move on Korea.

Near-term dollar trends are downward, geopolitical backdrop is tense (esp with N Korea) with no clear immediate resolution, and cryptocurrencies have become highly volatile and are less of a safe haven alternative.

Moving my forecasts up. Gold making a run at 1400 but suspect this will be short lived if world tensions cool. On the other hand, if back and forth between Pyongyang and Washington increase, might see 1400 surpassed by end of month.

Realized that I should be around 60-40 on this one at this late date rather than something like 80-20, partly because I have been leaning towards the >1300 bucket right from the start.  More importantly, there are indicators that the current rally is running out of steam. If so, it would be just perfect timing to briefly dip down below 1300 at the month end.

Granted we're right in the middle of the $1300-1400 range, yet, Tom McClellan's 13.5-month Gold cycle (https://www.mcoscillator.com/learning_center/weekly_chart/golds_13-1_2_month_cycle_right_translation/) points lower (into EOY), while recent outflows from GLD and GDX ETFs suggest an imminent correction (<$1300)..
Shifting up given the increase in gold prices.

I adjusted forecast to reclect ongoing uncertainty; however, looking past September, strong possibility of a pullback below 1300, due to 1) current price reflects current and future worries, and 2)  economic situation continues improvement/likely rate hike(s)/cost of carry lowers metal px.

As of 9/6/2017, the spot price is $1341.  Given the challenges of getting the national debt limit approved, the costs of paying for hurricanes in Texas and Florida, the North Korean situation, and a potential terrorist attack (we're overdue for one), the inclination for investors will be to retreat to "safe havens", foremost of which is Gold.
Mean 1338 SD 40.83 Adjustment and slight shift to right.

Haven't updated for some time. Currently at 1333.94 after NK test and only a few days to go. If the Federal Reserve actually hikes the interest rate, gold would become less attractive compared to the dollar, but gold becomes more attractive in Aug, Sept, Oct since 1975.  https://www.caseyresearch.com/gold-is-seasonal-when-is-the-best-month-to-buy/ My own (self-selected and therefore biased) data collection also shows a general increase in intra-day stock market volatility in these months, but with most of it happening in the first half of Sept (next 5 trading days). My guess is this correlates with tropical storms in the Atlantic. This seems like a U.S.-centric view, somewhat undermining my hypothesis, except that a lot of currencies are tied to the dollar quite strongly, and the volatility index (CBOE) primarily measures the S&P 500. With only 25 days to go, I would expect gold to move toward 1400, looking at futures contracts, the current implied volatility of GCV17 is 10.86% and there is a 95% chance that it would trade between 1250.92 and 1418.28, a 73.4% chance it would trade between 1300 and 1400, a 5.7% chance it would trade above 1400,  a 20.73% chance it would trade between 1200 and 20.8% chance it would trade below 1300. Anything at or under 1200 is neglible. 0.07% TL:DR; momentum shows gold resuming ascent, historical data confirms, and federal reserve rate hike would dent it slightly; and stock futures and implied volatility appear to offer a robust baseline.

six month timeframe for each new range - not a theory i can count on as past doesn't indicate future but feel 1335 is well within bucket range with deadline of 20 days stock market implosion before then and all bets are off but unlikely given market circuit breakers, oil low, housing bubbles deflated if rates rise slowly, consumer spending seems to be sane and tapering off. IOWs I see a move to 1400 bin if gold is a flight to safety and feel horizon is choppy but near term a lot has to happen before that's a thing

Think it unlikely that gold will break down again during this month, given the fact that N Korea is providing it with some extra ballast.
Raising 70% to 80%.
Risks continue to increase on the topside - can't see  how this reduces to in the next month
I think this is quite a significant breakout in gold. Will meet some resistence around 1350 but i think gold will break this level also.

A retraction of the current bull run will likely come in September, so it depends how high gold can climb before that to see if it drops back below 1300. The DPRK nuclear test will likely increase the risk off positions further helping the current surge in prices. The German elections at the end of the month are probably less significant given that a CDU win should be priced in already.

Seems within coinflip territory given the time remaining.
Political and economic uncertainties reliably feed goldbugs.  Things have not yet got as weird as they probably will.  I am very likely wrong about this.
Debt ceiling & geopolitical tensions have potential to keep Gold elevated over the next month - if we assume spot is well priced then there is a higher chance of being above 1300 than below

Now that the price has decisively taken out the $1300 level which was the big resistance, one is inclined to bet that September would end with a higher price level. $1400 level is probably too high to climb in one month, but with the breakaway momentum in evidence, it too is in play.

Yes -- Hunt for info. Share the evidence that helps inform your prediction.
Yes -- Adjust. Explain the reason for updating your prediction.

Now in upswing of shorter-term Gold cycle, risk to the upside. Will likely get a few week's price action around the all important $1300 pivot, before next major move.

Dropping to 50% from 58% in the second highest bucket since the time window is closing. Also, the rhetorical war with North Korea was a good time for the gold price to break free above $1300, but it didn't come about since it was beaten back at about $1290.

The market continues to creep higher, causing my forecast to adjust. Afraid I was wrong-footed from the start on this one. I thought rising real interest rates would cause gold to have a downward price bias over time. The bullish influence of a weakening USD has overwhelmed any impact downward price bias.
Wars and rumours of war are much beloved by gold bugs.  This should keep going up for a while.
Global instability, and the events that will transpire from now until the 29th will cause the price to spike.
Currently at 1266. Upside looks most likely as has breached 1300 a few times in past 6 months.
Starting to reduce the probability in the >$1300 bucket as the time window begins to close.
Shifting a bit toward the center as the price of gold as been very steady within that band since March

Moving up as expected. Touched $1270 today. 
Just transferring 3% from the lowest two buckets to the higher bucket.

Due to the weakness in the USD, I am increasing my outlook on gold from negative to neutral. I am a bit conflicted on this because history says the single biggest factor in the price of gold is real interest rates. If real interest rates are negative, one is wise to hold their wealth in gold, thus avoiding the depreciating buying power of currency. When real interest rates are high one is wiser to store one's wealth in currency denominated instruments and collect the return high real interet rates provide.  While we are in a rising real interest rate environment, the valus of the USD is declining steadily. This tends to be bullish all USD denominated commodities.  Simply assuming these two opposing forces cancel each other out to produce a neutral market. Also, assuming 10% volatility, more or less in line with recent history.

August and September are traditionally the strongest months in the gold market. 
http://palisade-research.com/golds-best-months-are-coming/ I think I am too aggressive with my forecast, but I am staying with it, given that the recent range bound action in the gold price is suspected to be over. Reason does suggest that a 50-50 forecast might be the better bet here, especially given that the last 2 spikes in the gold price were both beaten down just below the $1300 mark.

The bottom line is Gold behaves like a alternate currency over the longer term. Hence the gold price in US dollar terms should have only to do with the US economy(& inflation) and the global economy(& inflation). [open to discussing other factors but don't believe they are much of a factor]
Now, about the odds:
Close timeline=> high chance of not much happening in the economy=>putting a 90% chance of staying in current range. Dividing rest of 10% over the surrounding ranges, slightly skewed on the upside reflecting a slightly higher chance of something bad happening.

Cost of production $600-$800, it has some ground to reducing in price

The moment Trump puts his tax cuts proposal on the table, implying a rising budget deficit, inflation expectations should rise, and inflation hedges like gold should benefit somewhat. This is what happened for a few months after the 2016 elections. The proposal should normally be out by Sep 29, but the way things are going with other administration-proposed legislation, there may be a delay, in which case the current downtrend in gold's price should continue.

Sticking with the same general thesis of increasing real interest rates are bad for gold prices. Today's jobs data, along with slumping crude oil, just makes me more confident real interest rates are likely going up. Using -6% expected return, while keeping volatility at 12%.

If the FED moves to reduce its position and the stock market reacts negatively, gold should increase in value. I don't believe that the price of gold will go down significantly by the end of the year.

Eliminating any chance on 4th and 5th category, lowering to 15% 2nd, raising 3rd to 70%. The trend seems headed lower so the 2nd category is still in play but only 2 months left so the odds seem in favor of staying in between $1200 to $1300.
Using -7% expected return due to the rising interest rate environment, while keeping volatility at 12%. Rising real interest rates are not friendly gold prices.
Oil prices are stable and tied to gold prices
Raising 3rd category 5% and lowering 4th that amount. Gold hit resistance at $1300 and reversed.

Gold rose 1% last week. LIBOR continues to climb, creating an unfreindly environment for gold. I moved my expected one year return from -6% to -7% given the 1% decline last year, while keeping volatility at 12%. All of the aforementioned, adjusted probabilities toward the lower levels slightly.

Gold fell another 1% last week. LIBOR continues to climb, creating an unfreindly environment for gold. I moved my expected one year return from -7% to -6% given the 1% decline last year, while keeping volatility at 12%. All of the aforementioned, adjusted probabilities toward the lower levels slightly.

Given an offsetting bearish position in the 20-40 year Gold cycle vs. bullish 8 year cycle, no major moves expected this year. Closer in, current position in the ~155 trading day cycle indicates another ~7 weeks lower, then higher into this question's deadline—net effect is likely price neutral.

I'm going against the current consensus, which gives a 57% chance of gold being between $1200 and $1300 on Sept 29, 2017.  My logic may be wrong, but it's simple.  If the trend established since the beginning of 2017 continues then gold will exceed $1300 within three months. Political or economic events could cause a diversion from this trend at any time.  Supply and demand factors also greatly affect the price; traders and others closer to the market may be able to predict these.  I have no familiarity with supply and demand factors (gold purchases in China and India, mining output, etc).  I'm simply projecting that we will either continue the current trend, or there will be a political event, possibly Trump induced, that causes gold to break above the trend.  Either way my guess is that we'll end up above $1300.  My 2¢.

Gold market seems resilient to FED-decision for higher interest rate. Risk for financial system remains high, but nobody knows when the showdown will start. Market oscillates between 1200 and 1300 $ in 2017.

Between 1978 and 1979, gold prices increased 120% and the spike was likely highly correlated to the gas crises.  Besides the market correction in the early 1980s, the most significant decrease was in 1997 and almost certainly correlated to the beginning of the tech boom.  Gold prices seem to be tied to current events more than all major financial instruments.  In my opinion, gold is the standard indicator for the knee jerk investor that leans towards paranoia.  The Trump administration is headed towards serious troubles, but in my experience the average gold investor leans to the right and may react slower to Republican problems.    http://onlygold.com/Info/Historical-Gold-Prices.asp

Current price $1268. Bounced off resistance at $1300. No change for now but I see more upside then downside on political instability. The FOMC rate decision could cause short term price drop. Support at $1200.

Keeping volatility at 12% and reducing expected return form -8% to -7% since the market fell 1% last week. LIBOR continues to climb, rising real interest rates are traditionally an unfriendly environment for gold prices.

Should be a good few months for the gold bugs, who usually do better as things get stranger.  Stay tuned.
I remain skeptical that the price is going to stay above $1,300.  There is a decent chance it will even go below $1,200.  http://allstarcharts.com/will-time-buy-gold/
Currently $1278.77. No change at this time. Currently trending up next resistance approx. $1300.

Reducing volatility to 12%, it seems we are in a lower vol environment in a number of commodities, but lowering the expected return to -8%. In spite of the recent rally, I am still thinking gold should be under pressure in this higher interest rate environment. 30 day LIBOR has moved from below 1.00% in mid-May to above 1.075% today.
Inflation and other gold-bullish forces are stabilizing, and with the passage of time less chance of a flight to safety, hence going back stronger on < $1,300.

Assuming -5% expected price in the next year and 15% volatility. The negative return is due to an expected rising interest rate environment and gold's typical inverse relationship to real interest rates.

An environment of rising real interest rates is bearish gold, an alternative store of wealth to currency. If real interest rates increase, making the return of holding currency greater, money generally flows out of gold and into currency. For this reason, my forecaast has a slight downward bias.

Gold price in USD can reflect USD volatility as well as gold. 
If gold breaks through low resistance it may keep going towards $700 (probably due to a USD problem/deflation)
Shifting very slightly (2 points) toward 1200-1300 given gold's continued stability in that band.

Current futures at $1255. 1 st category remains 0, raised 2nd by 5%, raised 2nd by 10%  lowered 4th by 5%, lowered 5th category by 10%. Gold bugs should keep 1st category unlikely. Gold as a hedge remains a strategy so I am mildly bullish on it due to political environment. Fifth category unlikely but on any major negative political event I will reevaluate.
The last couple of years show the price of gold hovering in the $1100-1200 range.
The value of gold has a history of rising during times of political, economic & global unrest.

Increasing 3rd and 4th slots by 10% and decreasing 1st slot to 0 chance, 2nd slot down by 5% and upper slot by 10%. Seems to be a lot of political instability and if Pres. Trump can't resolve his popularity  and legal issues gold could benefit as a hedge.

My bet is that the long term interest rates will rise slower than what most forecasters think which should be supportive for the price of gold. Also, with the stock market valuations getting higher and higher, the possibility for a sharper correction are getting elevated which may support gold prices too.

With the current inflationary trends (linked to oil & energy prices among other things) as well as a bond market relieved from short term instability fears, I would not bet on large swings in gold prices as of now
Reducing the >1400 bucket and giving it to the two buckets below it.

I used data from http://onlygold.com/Info/Historical-Gold-Prices.asp from 2015 to 1955. Was only interested in volatility. Today gold costs 1262, so I calculated how many years saw as high price changes as in our five options. Results: In % of the years that saw changes of the kind ...
11% are falls of more than 12%
10% are btw -12 and -5%
34% btw -5 and +3%
11% 3 and 10% 
32% more than 10% + Historically gold either stays the same. Jumps upwards by 20-100% or falls by more than 10%.
We have less time than a year. Sort of half a year. I fudge the money so they get closer to the middle.

Today's price: $1262. Strengthening the middle bracket slightly after a decline corresponding to the French elections first round. 29 September is five days after the German elections so a similar reaction is likely. August and September futures are also pretty tight around the spot price.
In the meanwhile: 
 - Fed hike in June is looking less likely (although markets could be overreacting again) +
 - Possible correction of equity markets ++
 - Inflation seems to have peaked for the time being, driven by stagnating oil prices -
Keeping same levels for now. Waiting on reaction for investor reaction to Trump reversals on campaign promises.
Might see potential upside near-term on risk aversion (European elections); Fundamentals for gold still ok - Indian demand to remain firm on  festival-related buying.
Trump's policies are inflationary, economy is recovering, and geopolitical risks rising, not to mention bubbly equity markets.
I see more upside potential for gold prices based on political instability.

Going for a higher price as the Trump effect seems to fade, coupled with the re-adjustment to three Fed hikes in 2017, instead of four. Its difficult to know if a June hike is currently priced in (the market expectation is 50/50), but since two further hikes this year are broadly expected, I don't think a hike in June will significantly lower gold, unless the FOMC members' expectations for future hikes returns to four in 2017. Inflation is currently outpacing both the Fed (not to mention the ECB and the BOJ) as well as growth, which supports gold as an inflation hedge.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-29/gold-seen-soaring-by-incrementum-as-inflation-starts-to-kick-in

In my admittedly minimal experience, gold prices seem to fluctuate based on political and economic events. I realize that's not exactly a subtle observation but my point is I think gold will remain with the $1,200 to $1,300 band unless we have a political or economic shock in the next six or so months. In that case guess I'll be updating the forecast depending on how the news is handled.

The Gold price is most correlated to US Treasury yields and the US Dollar. Although I expect modestly higher treasury yields over the period of the question I forecast a lower US Dollar vs a basket of world currencies. The wildcard is more geopolitical tensions in the months to come which could boost Gold towards $1,400.

reaffirming.  something really spectacular would have to occur for gold to move above the 2016 high.  My forecast is based on looking at 10 year monthly chart of GLD.  Then applying a five wave elliott pattern down from the 2011 high.  I think we are in the midst of wave 5 down that should end at about 900.00.  Why 900?  there is a huge inverse head and shoulders that took place from 2008 to the end of 2009.  The neck line of that is about 900 (large volume support). For those that might ask why won't 2016 high be broke?  The last four months volume is not compelling.  depending on the next couple months and consensus here I will adjust upward from 33% in the "Between $1,100 and $1,200, inclusive" slot.

I have no view on what will happen to the gold price. This analysis is purely based on historic volatility.
Current gold price = $1258
Historic gold prices available on FRED. Volatility of monthly returns has been around 4.5% over the last 30 years (which excludes extremely high volatility in early 80s and mid 70s. Converts to 7 month volatility of around 11.9% (multiply by square root of 7). As a cross check, this is broadly consistent with 6 month volatility over the last 30 years.
Percentages are relatively compressed as the bands are not very wide. The probabilities are not affected hugely by using slightly different volatility assumption.
Tails are too small.  Increasing them.

Am pretty sure the bear market in gold got over with it dropping below 1100 a few months back. Now it is in the early stages of a new bull market. The time period of the question is right for it to make a decent move above 1300. Can't tell whether it will get above 1400 in the move though.
Good question, but not sure of the timeframe. I'll guess wildly in the dark, because if I could accurately price gold, I would be a multi millionaire.
